customer_addr:
15412 Front Beach Road
Panama City Beach, FL 32413

citations.narrative:
The facility failed to keep the exhibit areas and grounds clean and in good repair. Multiple repeat violations have been
cited for failure to maintain the enclosures in good repair. Loose fragments of broken cement were observed and
documented from inspections dated: Oct 23, 2024 – INS-0001164318, January 18, 2025 – INS-0001225149, March 27,
2025 – INS-0001356180, May 13, 2025 – INS-0001316106, and again on June 2, 2025 – INS-0001359593. The necropsy
report for the bottle nose dolphin, Samira, that was found deceased in her enclosure on May 27, 2025, states, “Gross and
histologic examination of the gastrointestinal tract revealed five variably shaped fragments of hard material suspected to
represent ingested concrete flooring from the enclosure.” Medical records document that this animal was exhibiting
abnormal eating behavior prior to death.
Failure to maintain buildings, grounds, and exhibit areas clean and in good repair can expose the animals to loose or
jagged material that could be harmful to the health and well-being of the animal.
Primary enclosures housing marine mammals must not have any loose objects or sharp projections and/or edges which
may cause injury or trauma to the marine mammals contained therein. To be corrected from this day, August 29, 2025,
forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.107(c)  Critical
   
Sanitation. 
The facility failed to keep the exhibit areas and grounds clean and in good repair. Multiple repeat violations have been 
cited for failure to maintain the enclosures in good repair. Loose fragments of broken cement were observed and 
documented from inspections dated: Oct 23, 2024 – INS-0001164318, January 18, 2025 – INS-0001225149, March 27, 
2025 – INS-0001356180, May 13, 2025 – INS-0001316106, and again on June 2, 2025 – INS-0001359593. The necropsy 
report for the bottle nose dolphin, Samira, that was found deceased in her enclosure on May 27, 2025, states, “Gross and 
histologic examination of the gastrointestinal tract revealed five variably shaped fragments of hard material suspected to 
represent ingested concrete flooring from the enclosure.” Medical records document that this animal was exhibiting 
abnormal eating behavior prior to death.  
 
Failure to maintain buildings, grounds, and exhibit areas clean and in good repair can expose the animals to loose or 
jagged material that could be harmful to the health and well-being of the animal. 
 
Primary enclosures housing marine mammals must not have any loose objects or sharp projections and/or edges which 
may cause injury or trauma to the marine mammals contained therein. To be corrected from this day, August 29, 2025, 
forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
